Lords of the Fallen is my favorite "Not From" Souls game, and yes, I know that it might sound a bit odd, seeing the reviews sitting on "Mixed".

So why? Well, let me start with gameplay. All in all, a smooth experience. I never felt like the game was clumsy, dodges are substantial and I frames pretty forgiving like in actual modern From Software games, avoiding the usual issue where dodging attacks feels more like a chore then actual fun. Hitting an enemy just "Feels" good, the sound feedback and blood splatter makes the combat feel visceral and entertaining. Enemy move sets feel pretty fair, as do their healthbars (Besides a few annoying exceptions, but let's be real, which souls game doesn't have at least one of those?) And Bosses? Honestly, both in their design, fight OST, arenas and movesets, almost every single boss becomes a major highlight.

Exploration feels nice. The areas are well designed, linear in spirit, but enough nooks and crannies to find secrets and extra stuff in. This is doubled by using the "Umbral Realm" to access different areas. Again, there are a few areas where you roll your eyes on subsequent playthroughs, because they are REALLY annoying, but again, it kind of follows the Souls spirit in that regard.

Graphically, the game looks stunning. Armors are really well designed, fashion souls is very strong in this game, you can create some insanely cool looking characters depending on your taste. Build variety follows suit, while obivously we can all argue about what's the "Meta", I tried out a bunch of different weapons, magic schools and styles, all of them working fairly well.

Now, all of this is "Up to taste". Even among my friends, while they like the game, they wouldn't call it their favorite. Some of you might enjoy for example Lies of P more, some of you might gravitate towards Nioh. But to me, Lords of The Fallen is really close to feeling like Dark Souls 3, in atmosphere, design and gameplay, which just scratches a specific itch.

One thing that I have to say though, in the unlikely case that someone reads this review and decides to buy this. If you're just starting out, I'd recommend to turn OFF multiplayer. A major flaw in my opinion is the Invasion matchmaking, as you WILL be invaded by players ten times your level that you stand no chance against whatsoever. When you level up enough, turn that bad boy back on and go crack some skulls, but as a low level, especially as a beginner, beware.

I realize the majority will choose a From Software game over this one, but for some inexplicable reason I cannot get enough of LotF. It's a pleasant surprise. The combat system is smoother than Elden Ring, the leveling grind is balanced offering rewards and incentivizing the grind. My biggest gripe with the game is the quest tracking / journal system. It's absolutely horrid, and there are lots of things a new player will miss without realizing it. The game does suffer from some bugs as well, but not gamebreaking. The coop is what Elden Ring should have incoprorated, and CI does it very well on this game. Not a necessary update, but it would be nice to toggle PVP on/off without having to turn off multiplayer. Speaking of PVP, it's equally as horrid as the quest tracking. There is no equitable matchmaking so my advice is to turn off multiplayer when playing solo till you're ready to dip your toes. Overall, this game is a solid 4 to 4.5 out of 5. The quest tracking and PVP really prevent me from giving it any higher rating at this time.

It is a bit confusing trying to figure out how to play the shared progress co-op but other than that loving the game!  My friend and I have about 30 hours each.  Story is very good and the combat feels fluid and responsive.

Edit: My original review was too harsh. Yes, there's occasional stutters and occasional jank. The parry is occasionally awkward and occasionally inconsistent windows. It's also possible to go in the "wrong" direction and be under-leveled, only to later find new areas where you're over-leveled. The lock-on system is still janky where it seems to lock onto where your *character* is facing, not the camera, meaning that when you're running around an enemy, you'll often point the camera in the wrong direction instead of locking on the enemy. The PvP mechanic can have people invading at the worst times.   
   
Yes, this is all annoying, but if you can get through it, the game is really good. The combat is (usually) satisfying. The story is interesting, though a bit cryptic. The umbral-realm mechanic is fun. If you like souls-like games, just get it and play.
  
Original review: It's good except when it's not (in the "bad game" way, not the "dark souls" way). "Not good" meaning "unintentionally annoying" not "intentionally difficult". When hit boxes get screwed up (e.g. me swinging thru an invincible dog or hits catching me after successful dodges or hits that would normally stagger suddenly stop staggering) or inputs fail to register (e.g. unable to dodge right after a parry or parry not happening because the game stuttered on a boss) or when multiplayer gets weird (e.g. spawning outside a fog gate to watch my summoner slowly die) or the camera gets weird (e.g. boss appears next to a wall causing camera to go behind a curtain and you can't see anything). When any boss can one- or two-shot me, any of these jitters and bugs take any encounter from "hard but fair" into "the game is literally trolling me and trying to make me angry". Real difficulty means testing the player in a consistent way, not inconsistently messing with them in chaotic ways. Small input problems make all the difference between a good and bad souls-like.
Other than that, good game. I really like the mechanics, the world, the umbral-realm mechanic, etc.

Combat feels clunky, enemy placements are cheap, and don’t even get me started on the performance issues. For $60? Absolutely not. This feels like a $20 early access title wearing a triple-A price tag.

Only redeeming quality? Some of the visuals. But pretty graphics can’t carry a game this broken.

Avoid unless it’s on a deep sale or you’re into digital masochism.

The game has all the right ideas but not enough content or polish. I might've left a mixed review if there was one, but I did enjoy the game until I got further in and would probably buy a sequel if it improved on the enemy design and built a more interesting game world to explore.

The most obvious flaw the game has is repetitive enemy placements, and the few unique enemy types and bosses feel more so awkward rather than interesting to fight.

The game does a solid job however of making the player character feel good to control and gives a good number of equipment choices and build variety with fun to use movesets.

My biggest gripe however is you can't switch weapons without entering a menu, which just feels like a missed chance to help spice up the game a bit by giving you more situational weapons rather than just picking one that has the most all-around usage.

In conclusion, try it out on a sale, or play it for free with a friend, it's fun even if it could've been a lot better.

Lords of the Fallen (2023): A Rocky Return That’s Finally Finding Its Feet

The Lords of the Fallen (2023) had a notoriously rough launch, and honestly, it wasn’t hard to see why. At release, the game was plagued by frustrating bugs, clunky combat, and performance issues that made what should have been a rewarding soulslike experience feel like a slog. Many players were left wondering if the remake was even worth their time.

Thankfully, the 2.0 update changed a lot. It brought much-needed improvements to enemy AI, smoother combat mechanics, and stability fixes that significantly reduced crashes and frame drops. The patch also polished the level design and pacing, making exploration more engaging and less tedious.

That said, even with the update, the game still struggles to fully capture the magic of its genre’s best. The story remains underwhelming, and some design choices feel dated compared to its contemporaries. But the core combat feels tighter, and the atmosphere is intact, offering a decent challenge for fans willing to give it another shot.

In the end, Lords of the Fallen remake is no masterpiece, but thanks to the 2.0 update, it’s moved from a disastrous launch to a playable and sometimes enjoyable soulslike experience. It’s a work in progress that’s heading in the right direction, even if it hasn’t quite arrived yet.

Although I prefer traditional RPGs to souls-like games, I really enjoyed Lords of the Fallen 2.0. World exploration, character progression, and combat are all very fun. I would suggest, however, a walk-through to help navigate the game and get the most out of it. And although there is re-playability with NG+ and different endings, I found a single, complete run was satisfying enough. I got the game on sale but it's definitively worth full price in my opinion. Looking forward to expansions/sequels!

Game is great! I like the new concept of having two realms for player to toggle back and forth, solving and unlocking maps. 

HOWEVER, IF YOU ARE PLANNING TO BUY THE GAME TO PLAY WITH YOUR FRIENDS IN CO-OP MODE:
- A LOT OF BUGS THAT NEED TO BE ADDRESSED, i.e. I'm the guest and my friend is the host, but the host doesn't have the pop-up messages when interacting with objects/npcs/ anything sometimes, or our screens don't see the same mobs or items dropped even though we are playing in the same session. 
- CRIMSON RITUAL MODE (FORCED PVP MODE): the main reason I'm buying this game is to play with my friends, and that means co-op. AND having people force pvp into our campaign is really irritating as we are trying to clear the game together. It's not that bad if it wasn't for the fact that we cannot turn this mode off, as for a reason because we are doing multiplayer online, I wish the devs could come up with a mode just for two persons only and share the progression (private session with no force pvp, pretty much).

Overall, I'd recommend you try this game IF you are doing solo/playing alone. Personally, if you are playing with friends, I would not recommend it, at least until the new patch would address the problems I believe most of the players are having!
